comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
William Ritchie & Sons, Ltd. (WR&S)   1902-1928 
London, England and Edinburg, Scotland

A publisher of a great number of view-cards depicting Great Britain and Ireland. Most were issued under the Reliable Series name. Their cards were printed in a variety of techniques but mostly as tinted collotypes

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
Easons  must have been engaged to take the photos for W.R. & S

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/clearwood/8059071155/]

comment.author: 30522394@N00
comment._content: Note that many Irish sundials are wrong. This is because Irish time was defined legally as the local mean time up until 1880, when it was defined as the mean time at Dunsink Observatory, Dublin. This meant that Irish time differed by about 25 minutes from GMT. It was only in 1916 that Irish time was brought into line with GMT See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Time_in_the_Republic_of_Ireland

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: The Sundial Limerick An Hilarious Owl once made his home on A square tower without a round dome on. "Too-whit and too-whoo I just love the view - But it's painful to perch on the gnomon!"

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/ronanconroy] I thought that as in England, twelve noon was when the sun was at its zenith and the rest of the day was divided around it, thus putting Westport ten minutes behind Dublin, and it wasn't until the introduction of railway time that the time was standardised across the country (though as you point out, it may have been standardised wrong - or is GMT wrong?).

comment.author: 92418093@N08
comment._content:
The gnomon's for telling the time,
And the owl's become part of the rhyme,
But as the sundial's blade
Is so often in shade,
The reading's just not worth a dime.

That Irish time's not GMT
Isn't really surprising to me.
If it relies of the sun
To read: quarter to one,
It's probably quarter past three.
